title.narrative: Strengthening the humanitarian response to conflict-affected populations in north-east Nigeria

description.narrative: There are an estimated 7 million people in need of assistance in Nigeria(OCHA), including approximately 1.9 million displaced by the insurgency (IOM DTM round IX) which started in late 2014. 92% of the IDPs are hosted by under-served host communities, bringing already stretched services and resources under increased pressure. The armed conflict directly affected four states in the North East: Adamawa, Borno, Gombe, and Yobe States. The current humanitarian response covers all four states directly affected, with Borno State being the epi-centre of military operations and displacement of civilians. However, the responseis significantly hampered by very limited funding to meet such large needs, the challenges of response actors to scale up in the affected areas with qualified personnel with emergency profiles and the delays inthe recognition of the Boko Haram crisis as a humanitarian crisis beyondnational capacity. Two years into the crisis some progress has been achieved, but with only 69%of people being reached, the response needs to be scaled up, building on the access, partnerships and field presenceand activities put in place.

participating-org.narrative: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

title.narrative: Enhancing regional convergence of data collection, analysis and dissemination through the displacement tracking matrix (DTM)

description.narrative: The proposed project aims to enhance regional convergence of data collection, analysis and dissemination through the implementation of three interconnected pillars of activities: I) to undertake in-depth studies on factors shaping different groups of migrants’ decisions to leave their country and chose a route and destination, with a particular focus on forced mobility (year 1) and II) to coordinate and strengthen cross-country and cross-regional data collection and data analysis which links information about mobility patterns with findings regarding the underlying factors that shape migration decisions, seeking to link debates on forced, irregular and regular migration, as well as making the connection between internal and cross-border mobility dynamics, with a strong gender component (year 1-3), and III) to strengthen IOM’s cooperation with OCHA-Hoxton further enhance data interoperability and information sharing mechanisms (year 1-3). This stands to contribute to a fuller and more comprehensive understanding of human mobility patterns that can inform operational actors as well as policy makers and academia on required actions to address and mitigate root causes and to enhance avenues for migration that mutually benefits migrants and society. The project will build upon commitments by other donors, most notably DFID, which is supporting IOM activities to foster a greater understanding of migration flows in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Syria, Turkey, and along the Western Balkans and Mediterranean route, and is initiating a new project to support the establishment of flow monitoring points in Western and Central Africa.

title.narrative: Capacity building of Nepal's national security forces in camp coordination and camp management (CCCM)

description.narrative: Through the present project, IOM aims to contribute to the Government of Nepal's efforts in disaster preparedness through increasing capacity of first responders to effectively manage displaced populations in line with international standards and best practices. A comprehensive response in camp management aims at improving the quality of life and dignity of affected populations during displacement through engagement in participatory processes, working together with, and advocating on behalf of, internally displaced people, as well as other persons affected by humanitarian crisis. The National Red Cross Society (NRCS), as one of the key local responders in Nepal, will also participate in the capacity building activities to bridge the gap between immediate response and longer term management of displaced populations provided by international, national and local stakeholders. The proposed action will be implemented over a two-year period and in close coordination with Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA), Ministry of Defense (MoD), Ministry of Urban Development (MoUD), Department of Urban Development and Building Codes (DUDBC), NA, NP, APF, NRCS and their regional and district offices, and with the support of IOM's Global Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) Cluster team.

mailing-address.narrative: Tabarre 27, # 11Rue E. Pierre Zone de l’Ambassade des Etats-Unis, Port au Prince, Haiti

title.narrative: Emergency sanitation, hygiene and protection assistance to Congolese refugees

description.narrative: The aim of this project is to improve emergency sanitation, hygiene and protection assistance to affected Congolese refugees and vulnerable communities by: 1) ensuring Uganda’s immigration and government officials are able to rapidly respond to a sudden influx in refugees from DRC and abide by international protection guidelines and protocols, as well as 2) reduce the risks of propagation of WASH related diseases among the refugee population and host communities through improved access to sanitary facilities and improved hygiene and sanitation practices at Sebagoro landing site and Kyangwali settlement.

mailing-address.narrative: Plot 6A; Bukoto Crescent, Kampala, Uganda

title.narrative: Humanitarian Assistance to vulnerable migrants, IDPs and host communities in Yemen

description.narrative: While the number of new migrant arrivals to Yemen remained unabated in 2016 and 2017, IOM Migrant Assistance and Protection activities continued to expand. Therefore, in line with IOM’s larger migrant assistance and protection portfolio, the activities proposed herewith aim to provide life-saving assistance to vulnerable conflict-affected, destitute and stranded migrants in Yemen, including new arrivals along the country’s vast coastline where IOM would like to strengthen its presence. The project proposes to continue the Organization’s effort to conduct sea and air evacuations, mainly for vulnerable Ethiopian migrants and Somalis, stranded in various parts of the country and desperately wanting to go home.

title.narrative: IOM Country Level Support - Appeals 2018

description.narrative: Canada's multi-country support to provide humanitarian assistance to vulnerable populations. IOM will provide multi-sectoral assistance, including protection, shelter, emergency non-food items, health, WASH livelihoods and camp coordination management.

title.narrative: Enhancing human security for vulnerable displaced populations and host communities in South Sudan

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to contribute to preventing, reducing and mitigating serious protection concerns of vulnerable populations in South Sudan. Through this project, IOM will provide health care services, shelter and non-food item (S-NFI) assistance and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Promotion (WASH) services to Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and vulnerable host communities. Through these interventions, IOM will continue to address critical life-saving needs in prioritised locations. At the same time, IOM will actively identify opportunities and where possible find linkages between humanitarian assistance and transition activities, including through a Government of Japan proposed project for peace building and community stabilization.

mailing-address.narrative: IOM Compound New industrial area, Northern Bari, Juba, South Sudan

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving primary health care, WASH services and protection assistance to the vulnerable people affected of the Kasai crisis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

description.narrative: The project intends to contribute to addressing the humanitarian situation in Kasai region, especially to improve living conditions of women and men affected by Kasai crisis and host communities in Kamonia health zone including major cross border town Kamako where many of the displaced Congolese in Angola crossing the border to return home villages. The proposed project will provide life-saving healthcare and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) services and necessary protection assistance including provision of nutrition and gender-based violence (GBV) support and distribution of essential household items.

title.narrative: Enhance reception, management and Shelter conditions at IDP sites in Nganzai, Pulka and other locations in Borneo State, Nigeria

description.narrative: In North-East Nigeria the security situation remains unstable and violent with continuing attacks and incessant counter-insurgency activities; a situation which has resulted in prolonged insecurity. Through this project, IOM aims to contribute to the improvement of living conditions of IDPs and affected populations in Borno State in North-East Nigeria through improved site management and upgrade in services delivered to displaced populations.

title.narrative: Providing Life-Saving Transportation Assistance to Refugees in Tanzania

description.narrative: Since July 2017, Burundian refugees have been urged in various public fora by senior government officials in Tanzania to return home. To complement ongoing humanitarian efforts to provide for emergency and protection needs of refugees in Tanzania, IOM will: 1) provide refugees, with timely and safe transport, in a dignified manner, from entry points to camps, transfers from one camp to another, and/or for voluntary returns; and 2) ensure that each refugee in any mode of movement under IOM care, undergo a pre-embarkation medical screening, to ascertain fitness to travel, identify medical conditions that require further medical care, and/or for medical referrals.

title.narrative: Research, design and publishing of a manual for community-based psychosocial support programming in emergencies, displacement and return situations

description.narrative: In line with the IASC MHPSS guidelines, and in coordination with the IASC MHPSS working group, academic and professional centres and NGOs, IOM is elaborating and piloting a manual on community based MHPSS in emergencies. The manual will be based on research and a compilation of best practices, guidance notes, articles and documents on community based MHPSS programs implemented by IOM and other agencies. It will benefit IOM operations, but also and by default those of the various agencies active in Camp Coordination and Camp Management and those part of the IASC MHPSS group.
